Content-Type: text/plain; charset=UTF-8

From the scans, Celeron could tell that the crash had been caused by a large
capital ship.  Ships of that class were never intended to land in a plant's
atmosphere, so the fact that it had crashed here meant something had gone
terribly wrong.  Unfortunately, without proper equipment or aquatic bots, he
was unable to investigate any further and gave up the search; but it was
safe to say that between the mass of the object and the speed of reentry,
that the cause of the "tsunami" was probably this craft and not an
earthquake.

As the black-colored Predecon shuttle came into range of their base in the
Valley Mine Pentatron he began picking up some unusual signals of a group of
powerful bots, but as far as he could tell, they were not members of the
Bushido Predcons.  In an effort to stay off radar, he turned the scanners to
passive then activated the craft's jamming devices.  Then taking a wide
approach away from the more populated areas of the city, he slowly descended
toward the base.

Tag: Kratos, Creep, Rhinox (inside the base); anyone in Valley Mine

On Tue, Aug 18, 2009 at 1:17 PM, Kraftlos <kraftlos@...> wrote:

> The dark-colored Predecon shuttle zoomed over the waters of the
> Atlantic.  The tsunami had been detected within a few clicks of
> Atlantis, and it had no doubt been obliterated.
>
> Atlantis, however was not the target.  Celeron had detected the
> massive impact of a very familiar orbital, its mass and speed no doubt
> sufficient to cause such a tidal wave.  How strange that after all
> these years, it had suddenly crashed.
>
> Suddenly, scanners picked up a shallow area which he maps listed as an
> underwater mountain and a large reef above it.  At first he though he
> had found something, but there was clearly nothing different.
>
> There in the water, half a click out from the volcano, he spotted a
> large shadow underwater.  Pinging with the deeper scanners, revealed
> that this was it.  The call of treasure was irresitable.
>
> Celeron ordered the pilot to begin a descent to the surface.
>

--001485f723d0204c5f0490e548e5
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
